title: Michelle Pfeiffer gives Zoe Kravitz sage advice on playing Catwoman in The Batman
text:
Michelle Pfeiffer passed along a piece of advice for Big Little Lies star Zoë Kravitz, who was just cast as Selina Kyle/Catwoman in Warner Bros. Pictures' 2021 reboot, The Batman.

The 61-year-old Oscar nominee memorably played the whip-cracking femme fetale feline with nine lives in Tim Burton's 1992 sequel Batman Returns, which earned $266.8M at the box office.

'I'm so excited,' the Maleficent: Mistress of Evil actress told GMA co-anchor Michael Strahan on Wednesday.

'I'm so excited!' Michelle Pfeiffer (L) offered advice for Big Little Lies star Zoë Kravitz (R), who was just cast as Selina Kyle/Catwoman in Warner Bros. Pictures' 2021 reboot, The Batman

Earned $266.8M! The 61-year-old Oscar nominee memorably played the whip-cracking femme fetale feline with nine lives in Tim Burton's 1992 sequel Batman Returns with Michael Keaton

'Make sure, whilst designing the costume, they consider how you're gonna go to the bathroom. Minor detail, but it's an important one.'

Michelle had to wear her skintight black latex catsuit - created by costume designers Mary E. Vogt and Bob Ringwood - for 12-14 hours at a time with only one bathroom break at lunch during the six-month shoot.

Pfeiffer's sage advice to the 30-year-old daughter of Lenny Kravitz and Lisa Bonet came the day after Oscar winner Anne Hathaway congratulated her on Instagram.

'The biggest congrats to @zoeisabellakravitz on landing the role of a lifetime,' the expecting 36-year-old wrote on Tuesday.

'Well, one life anyway... ⁣Enjoy the ride, Selina #Catwoman!'

The Oscar winner previously played Selina Kyle in Christopher Nolan's critically-acclaimed three-quel The Dark Knight Rises, which amassed $1.085B at the global box office.

Other actresses to take on the role of cat burglar/Bruce Wayne's love interest include Halle Berry, Julie Newmar, Lee Meriwether, Eartha Kitt, Camren Bicondova, and Lili Simmons.

Zoë begins filming with Robert Pattinson's Batman in late 2019/early 2020 - beating out Alicia Vikander, Zazie Beetz, and Eiza González for the coveted role - according to Variety.

'It's very much a point of view-driven, noir Batman tale,' The Batman director Matt Reeves told THR in January.

'It's told very squarely on his shoulders, and I hope it's going to be a story that will be thrilling but also emotional. It's more Batman in his detective mode than we've seen in the films. The comics have a history of that. He's supposed to be the world's greatest detective, and that's not necessarily been a part of what the movies have been.

'I'd love this to be one where when we go on that journey of tracking down the criminals and trying to solve a crime, it's going to allow his character to have an arc so that he can go through a transformation.'
